title: Problem Statement
content:
Erdős Problem #1101 asks about 'good' sequences of pairwise coprime integers. Given such a sequence u with convergent reciprocal series, the integers not divisible by any uᵢ form a sparse set A. Erdős defined u as 'good' if gaps in A match the theoretical bound from sieve theory.

The two main questions:
1. Can a good sequence have polynomial growth? (Conjectured NO)
2. Can a good sequence have sub-exponential growth? (Conjectured YES)
mathContext: This connects sieve theory with questions about multiplicative sequences. The 'density' of A is ∏(1-1/uᵢ), and sieve theory shows gaps are at least (1+o(1))·tₓ·∏(1-1/uᵢ)⁻¹.

title: Mathlib Imports
content: We import all of Mathlib for access to **Nat.nth** (enumerating elements satisfying a predicate), **Summable** (convergent series), **StrictMono** (strictly increasing functions), and **Nat.Coprime** (coprimality).

title: The Sieved Set A
content:
**ASet u** contains all positive integers not divisible by any term of u. This is the set of integers that 'survive' the sieve defined by u.

For example, if u = {2, 3, 5, ...} (all primes), then ASet u = {1} since every integer > 1 is divisible by some prime.
mathContext: In formal notation: ASet(u) = {a ∈ ℕ : ∀i, uᵢ ∤ a}

title: Enumeration Function A
content:
**A u n** gives the (n+1)-th element of ASet u in increasing order, using Mathlib's **Nat.nth** function.

This lets us talk about gaps between consecutive elements: the gap at position k is A(k+1) - A(k).

title: The Product Index t
content:
The index **t u x** is the largest k such that u₀·u₁·...·u_{k-1} ≤ x. This measures how many terms of u have cumulative product at most x.

It appears in the gap bound formula and connects multiplicative structure (products) to additive structure (gaps).

title: The Good Sequence Predicate
content:
A sequence u is **'good'** if it satisfies four conditions:
1. Strictly increasing
2. Pairwise coprime
3. Convergent reciprocal series Σ1/uᵢ < ∞
4. Gaps in A are bounded above by (1+ε)·t·∏(1-1/uᵢ)⁻¹ for any ε > 0 and large x

The fourth condition says gaps are essentially optimal—matching the sieve theory lower bound.
mathContext: The gap bound formula connects the multiplicative structure of u (through the product formula) with the additive structure of A (through gaps).

title: Conjecture 1: No Polynomial Growth
content:
Erdős conjectured that **NO good sequence can have polynomial growth** uₙ = O(n^k).

The intuition is that polynomial-growth sequences don't have enough 'room' between their terms to satisfy the gap bound. This is axiomatized because it remains an **OPEN problem**.

title: Conjecture 2: Sub-exponential Growth Possible
content:
Erdős conjectured that there **IS** a good sequence with sub-exponential growth: log(uₙ) = o(n).

This means uₙ grows slower than any exponential e^(cn). The gap between polynomial (too slow) and sub-exponential (achievable) is the heart of the problem.

title: Erdős's Existence Theorem
content:
Erdős proved that **SOME good sequence exists**—specifically, the sequence of all primes works.

This establishes that the 'good' condition is not vacuous. However, the primes grow like n log n (slower than any polynomial n^(1+ε)), so this doesn't resolve the growth rate questions.

title: Sieve Theory Lower Bound
content:
Classical sieve theory shows that gaps in A must be **at least** (1+o(1))·t·∏(1-1/uᵢ)⁻¹.

This is the lower bound matching the upper bound in the 'good' definition. The 'good' condition asks when this bound is essentially tight.
mathContext: Sieve methods give lower bounds on gaps by counting integers in intervals that survive the sieve. The product formula gives the expected density.

title: Connection to Problem #208
content:
**Problem #208** (strong form) asks whether the sequence of prime squares uᵢ = pᵢ² is good.

Since pₙ ~ n log n, we have pₙ² ~ n² log² n, which is polynomial growth. If prime squares form a good sequence, **Conjecture 1 is FALSE**. This makes Problem #208 a key test case.
